items.article_title: Your Block Is Hotter Than You Think

Your specific block might run five to ten degrees hotter than city averages suggest.

items.article_title: Urban Greening Backfires in Arid Cities Below 1000mm Precipitation
items.text:
Machine learning analysis of 761 megacities reveals vegetation cooling effectiveness reverses in arid regions.

Where does conventional wisdom fail?

European cities face steepest relative warming.

items.article_title: When the Houses Go Up
items.text:
Lia Frenchman's house shakes when big waves hit the seawall at high tide.

Frenchman has a good job.

https://www.anchor.is/docket/issue/19/science/article/9565

video_script.title: When the Houses Go Up
video_script.hook:
Lia Frenchman's house shakes when big waves hit the seawall at high tide.

Frenchman has a good job.
body_slides: She bought in 2020. First Avenue sits closest to the ocean.
King tides flood the street every winter now.
Thirty-five homes under construction half mile uphill.
The Quinault Nation's first residential building in decades.
Moving from tsunami zone to higher ground.
Good jobs don't guarantee safe ground anymore
video_script.voiceover_text: Lia Frenchman's house shakes when big waves hit the seawall at high tide. Frenchman has a good job. She bought in 2020. First Avenue sits closest to the ocean. King tides flood the street every winter now. Thirty-five homes under construction half mile uphill. The Quinault Nation's first residential building in decades. Moving from tsunami zone to higher ground. Good jobs don't guarantee safe ground anymore. The full reconstruction is at The Docket.
video_script.voiceover_cta: The full story is at The Docket.

items.article_title: An Interview with the Man Who Counts Dead Things for a Living
items.text:
Living the Climate Science CONTINUE READING

https://www.anchor.is/docket/issue/19/science/article/9566

video_script.title: An Interview with the Man Who Counts Dead Things for a Living
video_script.hook: Living the Climate Science CONTINUE READING
body_slides: His clipboard holds forty-three species. Today's count: zero.
The monitoring station sits empty. Wind through rusted equipment.
Same coordinates. Twenty-seven years of data. The silence grows.
He adjusts the broken thermometer. Still records the temperature.
Another empty sample bag. Another day without findings.
video_script.voiceover_text: Living the Climate Science CONTINUE READING Meet Dr. Sarah Chen. She documents species extinction in real time. Her lab processes 400 specimens weekly. Most arrive already dead. Climate shifts killed 60% faster than her models predicted. She's watched entire ecosystems collapse in a single season. The data doesn't lie. The timeline has accelerated. Someone has to count what we're losing while we debate what to save. There's more to this story. It's at The Docket.
video_script.cta: The last entry in his logbook reads: 'Study concluded. No specimens remain.'
video_script.voiceover_cta: When there's nothing left to count, the counter becomes the witness. And the witness becomes the warning.
image_prompts: Weathered hands holding a scientific clipboard with empty data columns, morning fog rolling through abandoned field station, portrait orientation
Rusted weather monitoring equipment on metal pole, cables hanging loose in desert wind, overcast sky, documentary photography style
Close-up of data logbook pages filled with zeros and blank entries, pencil marks showing years of fieldwork, natural lighting
Scientists hands adjusting broken analog thermometer mounted on wooden post, cracked glass face, golden hour lighting, desert landscape background
Empty specimen collection bag held against barren landscape, no signs of wildlife, muted earth tones, atmospheric haze

Atmospheric documentary photograph visualizing: He adjusts the broken thermometer. Still records the temperature.. Photojournalistic style, natural lighting, cinematic composition, 9:16 portrait, no text or UI elements.

Atmospheric documentary photograph visualizing: Another empty sample bag. Another day without findings.. Photojournalistic style, natural lighting, cinematic composition, 9:16 portrait, no text or UI elements.
voiceover_lines: Dr. Martinez has been counting for three decades. The numbers tell a story nobody wants to hear.
Equipment breaks down faster than funding can replace it. But the work continues.
Each empty data point is still data. The absence speaks volumes.
Precision matters even when there's nothing left to measure.
Zero is still a number. Sometimes the most important one.

items.article_title: Chief Heat Officer Field Operations Manual (Excerpt)
items.text:
Your hands present the mortality data: 602 heat deaths, down from 645 the previous year.

“improving coordination across existing structures.”

You call this progress.

https://www.anchor.is/docket/issue/19/lab/article/9627

video_script.title: Chief Heat Officer Field Operations Manual (Excerpt)
video_script.hook:
Your hands present the mortality data: 602 heat deaths, down from 645 the previous year.

“improving coordination across existing structures.”

You call this progress.
body_slides: Seven cities. Seven women. Managing heat like other emergencies.
Her phone buzzes. Another cooling center request. 97 degrees at 6 AM.
The grant application cursor blinks. 'Improving coordination across existing structures.'
Six hundred and two bodies. Counted. Filed. Preventable.
video_script.voiceover_text: Your hands present the mortality data: 602 heat deaths, down from 645 the previous year. “improving coordination across existing structures.” You call this progress. Your throat holds the phrase ready for the grant application. "improving coordination across existing structures". Six hundred and two people still died from preventable atmospheric conditions. Seven cities worldwide have created Chief Heat Officer positions since 2021. All held by women so far. Some jobs exist because we failed to prevent the need for them. The Docket has the full picture.
video_script.cta: The job exists because we failed to prevent it.
video_script.voiceover_cta: The position of Chief Heat Officer exists only because we failed to prevent the need for one.
image_prompts: Wide aerial view of a sprawling sun-baked city with heat shimmer rising from concrete, harsh golden light, emergency vehicles scattered like toys below
Close-up of weathered hands holding a smartphone showing multiple emergency alerts, early morning shadows, fluorescent office lighting casting harsh angles
Extreme close-up of computer screen with cursor blinking in grant application text, reflection of tired eyes in the monitor, sterile office environment
Document page with mortality statistics, red pen marking numbers, coffee ring stains on paper, natural light filtering through venetian blinds

Atmospheric documentary photograph visualizing: The grant application cursor blinks. 'Improving coordination across existing structures.'. Photojournalistic style, natural lighting, cinematic composition, 9:16 portrait, no text or UI elements.

Atmospheric documentary photograph visualizing: Six hundred and two bodies. Counted. Filed. Preventable.. Photojournalistic style, natural lighting, cinematic composition, 9:16 portrait, no text or UI elements.
voiceover_lines: They gave the heat a manager.
The emergencies arrive before the sun.
Progress fits neatly in bureaucratic language.
Each number was someone's last summer.

items.article_title: As Bad As It Gets
items.text:
When an aquifer hits its lowest point in decades, the restrictions tell you who really matters.

https://www.anchor.is/docket/issue/19/lived/article/9612

video_script.title: As Bad As It Gets
video_script.hook: When an aquifer hits its lowest point in decades, the restrictions tell you who really matters.
body_slides: Edwards Aquifer reaches lowest level in 35 years
Stage 5 restrictions declared for first time in history
1,233 permit holders must cut water use by 44%
San Antonio's 1.8 million residents stay at Stage 3
Steven Siebert presents charts to city committee in May
When the water runs out, the permits reveal the pecking order.
video_script.voiceover_text: When an aquifer hits its lowest point in decades, the restrictions tell you who really matters. The underground river that feeds South Texas is running dry, and the measurements don't lie. No one alive has seen restrictions this severe before now. Every major water user—farms, factories, utilities—forced into emergency rationing. But somehow the city's residents face gentler limits than the industrial users. One man with charts telling a room full of officials that this is as bad as drought gets. When the water runs out, the permits reveal the pecking order. The full story is at The Docket.
video_script.voiceover_cta: The full story is at The Docket.
image_prompts: Aerial view of cracked, exposed limestone formations of the Edwards Aquifer during severe drought, golden hour lighting casting long shadows across the parched landscape
Close-up of weathered hands holding official Stage 5 water restriction documents against a backdrop of dried grass and empty irrigation channels
Wide shot of abandoned farming equipment sitting in dusty, cracked fields with withered crops under harsh midday sun
Interior shot of San Antonio Municipal Utilities Committee meeting room with officials seated at curved desk, fluorescent lighting, serious expressions
Steven Siebert standing at podium presenting drought charts to committee members, dramatic side lighting through tall windows

items.article_title: What a Line in the Sand Looks Like at 8,000 Kilometers
items.text:
A farmer flew 8,000 kilometers to sue a country. And won.

https://www.anchor.is/docket/issue/19/systems/article/9579

video_script.title: What a Line in the Sand Looks Like at 8,000 Kilometers
video_script.hook: A farmer flew 8,000 kilometers to sue a country. And won.
body_slides: Onnie Emerenciana stood in The Hague courtroom. January 28.
Dutch judges ruled: The State violated his human rights.
Billions spent protecting European Netherlands. Bonaire got nothing.
Binding emissions targets ordered. Climate plan required by 2030.
Then he flew home to his grandmother's farm.
Justice measured in kilometers: 8,000 to get heard, zero to feel the consequences.
video_script.voiceover_text: A farmer flew 8,000 kilometers to sue a country. And won. While his island slowly drowns, Onnie traveled further than most people fly in a lifetime to demand protection. The court found the Dutch government guilty of climate discrimination against its own Caribbean territories. The same storms that barely register in Amsterdam can devastate an entire Caribbean community. For the first time, a court ordered a colonial power to protect its distant territories from climate change. Kunuku Mamai Rosa sits exactly where it always has, but the world around it keeps changing. Justice measured in kilometers: 8,000 to get heard, zero to feel the consequences. The full story is at The Docket.
video_script.voiceover_cta: The full story is at The Docket.
image_prompts: Wide shot of a small man in formal clothes standing before towering wooden panels in a Dutch courtroom, natural light filtering through tall windows
Aerial view of Bonaire's coastline showing eroded beaches and damaged coral reefs, harsh Caribbean sunlight casting stark shadows
Split scene showing modern Dutch flood barriers and infrastructure versus a simple Caribbean island settlement, documentary style contrast
Close-up of weathered hands holding legal documents against the backdrop of a small airplane on a tropical runway
A traditional Caribbean farm with large shade trees and simple buildings, golden hour light filtering through branches, mountains visible in distance

items.article_title: The $30,000 Question
items.text:
When Big Tech promises to save your dying town, someone else writes the check.

Climate news, adaptation, and speculation — every issue, free.
🔗 Link in bio

#ClimateChange #Adaptation #ClimateReality #ClimateCrisis #Documentary

video_script.title: The $30,000 Question
video_script.hook: When Big Tech promises to save your dying town, someone else writes the check.
body_slides: Richland Parish, Louisiana. Median income: $30,000.
Seven of eight cotton gins closed since 1990.
Meta arrives promising 500 jobs, transformation.
Power consumption: twice the size of New Orleans.
Local residents paying $2 billion for infrastructure.
In 2030 we'll learn what transformational actually costs.
video_script.voiceover_text: When Big Tech promises to save your dying town, someone else writes the check. This is what economic desperation looks like in rural America. The backbone of the local economy simply disappeared over three decades. When you're drowning, any lifeline looks good. Even one with strings attached. That's enough electricity to power a small city. For a data center. The fine print always reveals who's really paying for progress. The deal is done. The infrastructure is being built. In 2030 we'll learn what transformational actually costs. The full story is at The Docket.
video_script.cta:
Follow @docketclimate for more
Climate news · Adaptation · Speculation
Link in bio
video_script.voiceover_cta: Like and subscribe, and find more climate news, adaptation, and speculation at The Docket. Link in bio.
image_prompts: Weathered welcome sign for Richland Parish Louisiana, rust stains on metal, overcast sky, tall grass growing around the base, documentary photography style
Abandoned cotton gin facility, corrugated metal siding with peeling paint, broken windows, weeds growing through cracked concrete, golden hour lighting, vertical composition
Construction site with workers in hard hats, earth movers and concrete foundations, Meta data center under construction, industrial scale, morning mist, aerial perspective
Massive electrical transmission towers stretching across Louisiana farmland, power lines against gray sky, scale showing enormous infrastructure, documentary realism
Small wooden house with peeling paint next to massive construction cranes in background, stark contrast of scale, residents' pickup truck in driveway, moody lighting
